title: The Dulcie September case exposes France's troubling ties with South Africa during apartheid
subhead: Thirty-seven years after the unsolved assassination of the African National Congress (ANC) representative in Paris, a French court on Tuesday dismissed her family's complaint against the state for 'denial of justice' and 'gross negligence.'

Knife crimes: No miracle solution in the United Kingdom
subhead: Repressive laws, prevention and mentoring: Despite a range of approaches, the number of knife attacks in the UK has stabilized yet remains at an alarming level.

title: Tense standoff as a town in Northern Ireland braces for a third night of riots
subhead: Hundreds gathered on the streets armed with molotov cocktails, facing off against police armed with riot shields and backed by water cannons. UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer earlier on Wednesday condemned the 'mindless violence.'

title: Aragon and Catalonia battle over the 'Sistine Chapel of Romanesque art'
subhead: Spain's Supreme Court has given a museum in Barcelona 20 days to return mural paintings to the Monastery of Santa Maria de Sijena, from which they were removed in 1936 for protection during the Spanish Civil War.

title: The life and death of Julie, 21, swept up in the spiral of social media
subhead: Julie Pospieszny's tragic fate was that of a young woman of her generation, born into the age of social media and a victim of the violence it can unleash. Caught in the spiral of easy money and addicted to laughing gas, the influencer died in March. She was 21 years old.

subhead: From 'Surfin' USA' to 'God only knows,' the Beach Boys singer and song writer took pop music to new heights of sophistication through his mastery of the recording studio, before falling into drugs and depression. He died on Wednesday at 82.

title: In bed and on the job: How to stay productive while lying down
subhead: This practice has become entrenched since the Covid pandemic, creating a new kind of market. However, beware of the health risks it poses, notes Le Monde's Nicolas Santolaria in his column.
